This is a review of the game as it stands on release day.TL;DR SummaryPros Stardock's "most polished" 4X game on release in recent times, in the sense of being the least overtly buggy. Good quest variety and writing, particularly compared to Fallen Enchantress/Legendary Heroes Likely to be fun the first couple of times through. Prettier and more attractive UI compared to Stardock's own Fallen Enchantress/Legendary Heroes (but at the same time not in any way better than rival 4X titles like Endless Legends and Age of Wonders 3) Nice music.Cons Serious replayability concerns Narrow scope, and same base units no matter which sovereign you choose Crafting is too tedious particularly late game for what you get in return. Many balance and design issues that results in limited amount of actual, interesting, strategic choices and options. Lots of spells but you'll likely only end up casting a very small subset of them (i.e. plenty of unattractive spells - note that you'll have to sacrifice a unit's turn to cast a sovereign spell...) Actually manages to feel like a lesser game than its predecessors (Fallen Enchantress/Legendary Heroes) once you've this game figured out, though it provides gratification and fun sooner. Definitely a lesser game compared to the likes of Age of Wonders III despite being at the same price point.Verdict:A game that is designed to, and succeeds, in striking a great first impression. But once you've played a couple of games and grasped the mechanics, it is hard not to notice the many design and balance flaws as well as how shallow the game ultimately is. With time, these issues can hopefully be addressed but as it stands now, this game is hard to recommend at the $40 price point. Wait for a sale instead, and hopefully you'll get a patched and better balanced game in the process as well.In-depth reviewI find this game to be okay... There are quite a number of components that are better (e.g. quest variety) than Stardock's previous efforts in the Elemental series (Fallen Enchantress, Legendary Heroes) and the graphical and UI overhaul is largely welcomed. Many of the subsystems will feel very familiar to players who have played Legendary Heroes, including the not-particularly-tactical Tactical combat, right down to obscure stats like Spell Mastery (which is a different stat from Spell Damage). So, basically, I believe that if you like the premise of the game, if you have a certain fondness for 4X games, this will probably satisfy you to a degree and you'll have fun. If you like tactical combat (such as those found in the Heroes of Might and Magic series, as well as King's Bounty, and most notably Age of Wonders 3), you'll find yourself sorely disappointed. There _is_ a tactical element to tactical combat, it just doesn't feel particularly deep compared to the examples above. My personal misgivings about the game in its current state include: Longevity of the game once you have beaten it once. There are only two victory conditions after all and they'll play out the same no matter what. The only thing that differs is what playstyle you utilize to get there. And yes, while there are 6 sovereigns each with their own unique units/play style slant/gimmick, they ultimately all train the same base units which all utilise the same progression paths.  Concerns about balance - units like Enchanters are a late addition and don't feel like much thought has put into making them an interesting strategic option. At the moment, units like Enchanters and Clerics just feel entirely useless instead with how fragile they're and their low initiative (which means they take action very rarely, and pretty much die instantly if an enemy ranged unit looks at them funny, or if an enemy mage were to cast an AOE spell...) - you're much better off giving that precious army slot to another Paladin or Rider instead which brings so much more to the table in comparison... Given that Enchanters were added by Brad, the lead designer of the game, it doesn't inspire much confidence... (compare to the design process and goals that goes into games like League of Legends, the way the Enchanter was designed and added just feels random/adhoc).  Various obscure elements not well explained e.g. what do traits like Wisdom, Courage, Persuasion, Cruelty do (you pretty much find out only by watching the Stardock streams or searching the forums), with no way to look at what traits you've accumulated so far. What is the spell mastery stat (not explained in the Help sections, or manual, or tooltips)?  Concerns about the Crafting subsystem - It gets _really_ tedious late game, and there are issues... For instance, when you seemingly max out on Crafting recipes, the game doesn't handle it well (e.g. you can still attempt to trade for more crafting recipes, pay the price and get nothing in return). Alot of the spells/skills are not enticing - playing the Priest, I barely found the need to cast anything beyond Into the Light, Restore, and the occasional Refresh in tactical combat. Also, many of the sovereign skill trees do not offer choices that feel very compelling or rewarding. Note that you need to sacrifice your unit's turn to cast a sovereign spell in tactical combat, but I rarely found this trade off worthwhile. Iffy design concerns - I have concerns with general placement/layouts of the sovereign skill trees. As an example, I find inexplicable how "Enchanted Forges" is extremely early in many of the sovereign skill trees yet you can't actually build the corresponding Wonder to actually unlock enchanting until mid-late game...  On the other hand, +army size is fairly accessible for some of the sovereigns (e.g. Priest, strangely, who according to dev journals, was designed to have weaker/smaller armies), and extremely inaccessible for some of the others who really need it (e.g. the Guardian sovereign, who starts with a Ranger hero with skills that benefit ranged units as well as Tame Beasts yet struggles to find the army slots necessary to fit in frontline units/beasts and still have space for ranged backline). At the end of the day, the biggest concern is with longevity. You're ultimately playing a solo game here, and with there being only 2 ways to win, and with you going through the same motion and fighting the same boss every single time, with there being only 1 playable race, it is probably going to get old fast.And by the way, I thought I would just toss it out there that the asymmetric turn-based games has been done before - the campaign games of classics like Heroes of Might and Magic have you undergo similar jounreys to overcome asymmetric challenges. Within the 4X space, the campaign modes of games like Age of Wonders 3 pretty much offers the same (as well as a very satisfying sense of questing, levelling, progression, and more satisfying tactical combat). The problem is Sorcerer King is that the asymmetric premise is kind of the only thing you have going on, whereas all these other games, including Stardock's own past entires like Fallen Enchantress and Legendary Heroes, actually more ways to play and more races/classes to play with.At $40, this is a Not Recommended for me. Suggest that you wait and get this when it is on sale instead (hopefully the game will also be more polished then).Players who already own Legendary Heroes can get the game at $30 with the discount code from the Stardock store, and at the $30 price point, it still is hard to make a recommendation for this game in its current state with any conviction.

												Sorcerer King is a game that occupies a slightly different niche than other fantasy 4X games. In fact, if you go into this game expecting a typical 4X experience and challenge, you may well be disappointed. Yet, the differences are what made me really enjoy this game over its competitors.The way I prefer to see SK is as an RPG with a 4X control scheme. Sure, you build cities and expand your empire, but the main focus of the game is always on your champions. You explore the world, you find and do quests, you hunt for loot to craft new equipment, and get experience for your heroes so you can handle the final boss at the end. The strategy elements are still there, but downplayed compared to the RPG elements. This is the type of game for those of us who enjoyed our hero stacks in other fantasy strategy games.Also be warned that SK is a very text-heavy game. A lot of the quests, as well as the interactions between yourself and your various allies and enemies, are told through text boxes. The writing isn't especially deep, but is filled with humor and snark through-out. This keeps the writing interesting, even if it may seem a little jarring with the post-apocalyptic premise.I am personally much more of an RPG gamer than a strategy one, and so it surprised me how much I ended up truly loving Sorcerer King. It definitely gets my recommendation, and I'm eager to see how the game continues to develop.

												The majority of my hours were in EA and then like a sucker I've fired it up each patch to see if they've magically made it a good game.  I've played all of the Elemental titles and this is by far the worst.  It's a departure from the more traditional 4x genre but not in a good way.  It's more of a choose your own adventure mobile game in a cartoon setting.TLDR -Issue:  The game itself is really more of a single mission or scenario rather than a full fledged game.Single Player: It's "Won and done" as you're doing the same thing every single time.  Zero replayability, zero depth.  I know you're saying to yourself, "but you have 130 hrs in-game?"  Again, lots of EA skirmish time and a run through of each class can get you that sort of playtime.  However it barely matters what class you choose as you end up with all the same units and most of the same spells anyways.  Same mission everytime, same units everytime, same gear everytime - no matter your choices.  It's one dimensional and boring.MP:  NoneStory:  There isn't one, other than kill the bad guy.  Not that SD ever did a good job at developing the lore of Elemental but the little they did share is gone.  I felt like I was starting to get a feel for the factions, geography and lore after FE but that was all "streamlined" out.  I should note that SK in fact is a comedy.  The writing itself is comedic but it obviously doesn't fit the setting.  Honestly, it's comparable to walking around with Tosh 2.0 making fun of everything you see and everyone you talk to.  Again, it doesn't mesh with an end-time saga of survival. Graphics:  Plastic kid toons.  The visual assets and UI look like they were outsourced to the My Little Pony people.  Adds a layer of unwanted cheese and embarrassment.  I brought this up on the forum in EA and was told that people really like the Fisher Price look.  No, they really don't.  Your game didn't sell, people hated it.    Campaign:   Just when I thought Stardock couldn't offer any less of a campaign than they did in GC3 they went ahead and proved me wrong with SK.  It's quite literally a singular, static skirmish map with gate icons that partition the map and trigger text events.  I've been playing vids for 30 years and this is one of laziest efforts that I can remember.  I played a ton of early access thinking they were just getting warmed up with content and features for release but sadly they really weren't, it was obvious they had given up on the game months prior.Unfortunately this franchise is all but done.  They didn't see much of a future for it based on their effort, budget and execution.  It needed to get darker, deeper and more story driven to legitimize the franchise and instead they mailed it in with a silly, watered down mobile game.  It's efforts like this and GC3 that remind us that Stardock is really more of a publisher than a developer.  SK is a low end game that warrants $20 maximum.  I used to respect Stardock but it feels like they stopped respecting themselves and it shows in their poor quality games and DLC.

												Sorcerer King reuse many of the ideas of the previous iterations of the medieval-fantastic Stardock's 4X (Elemental: War of Magic, Fallen Enchantress sequels) and occurs in the same universe. It is graphically (both in terms of 3D and artwork) much better though, and its gameplay is slightly different despite several things in common.But like it predecessors, SK is unpolished and has countless infuriating game design flaws. To give a few examples, there are several city enchantments which are based on how many essences this city holds in its territory (essences is the source of magic or mana if you prefer). Those spells may for example add life, defense or initiative to the units trained in that city while the enchantment is active so the player is encouraged to find the richer spots in essence to build its cities and focus its production in them. But of course the tile yield is rarely shown (typically you need to "fertilize" lands with another mid-game spell to actually see the best spots) as only one terrain type (fertile) and its surroundings do actually give that information. This would not be so much of a problem if another game mechanic had been better thought, buildings and especially unique buildings which you cannot destroy. Typically the "Paladin" unit can only be built in one city due to a "1 per faction" building restriction on the construction that unlocks it. So building this in a low essence yield tile is of course a poor long term strategy, because you cannot destroy the building (well there is a work around which is to have some wandering monsters to destroy the whole city, but this again means you have to not have cleaned all the spawning camps in the area).While crafting/enchanting is definitely an interesting feature to have in a 4X game, the weapon bug is a pretty annoying one and I am very amazed that having purchased this game on sale a year after its release (I don't trust Stardock anymore as a developer I have to say, even if I keep buying their half-decent product I now always do it for half-price or less) that such a major and annoying bug is still around. Basically you can equip weapons on all of your units, but some have a level requirement. If the feature works for heroes, for all the regular units it simply does not even if your unit have the appropriate level and using the appropriate type of weapon. I read there is a work-around which consist to enchant the weapons, save the game and reload. I played without crafting/enchanting weapons so far so I will confirm (and edit here) at later stage if I ever do check this solution. But hell, seriously... what self-respecting developer would leave such a major bug in its beloved product for its beloved community to enjoy so much time after the official release? Well, one who doesn't care about any of the latter maybe?Don't get me wrong, besides the lack of polish and lack of interest in delivering its still loyal audience near flawless products (speaking of the in-house ones, as third party publishing of Stardock delivered some gems), this game is still an enjoyable 4X with some good ideas. Quest writing does not take itself seriously at all and there was a lot of effort put in making the narration diverse and fresh. Although the concept of the Sorcerer King allowing you to grow at the same time as trying to punish you for doing so turns out to be very secondary at the end (and basically when you master your expansion, you will just ignore him and your doomday counter will remain at zero, while you play the game like any other 4X) and it become near to irrelevant feature.The replayability is pretty low at the end, as the balance between the trainable units is pretty bad (unless you rely on other factions'troops in which case you may have more options than with "indigenous" ones) despite a good effort in diversifying the 6 playable character classes. Each class has its own specific "empire skill tree" and core spells which are definitely going to assymetrically affect your expansion and strategies, and then you can choose a starting hero and a unique spell (provided you wanna optimize your leader for a specific strategy instead of using the standard ones, for synergies like large armies of the Commander combined with the ranger hero massive bonuses to ranged units). This is certainly where the game is very exciting and fun as indeed there are a few possiblities available for the creative player.Also, once you understood what are the self-defeating game mechanics in this game spamming "crusade" and "destiny's gift" which are not only cheap to cast but also overpower every other unit enchant and grindy crafting, it becomes quickly uninteresting/unchallenging once you reach mid-game. Obviously what Stardock lacks is a proper, passionnate testing team or they should learn to listen to relevant feedback in their community (preferably early on with Beta testers). I could go on with "guide-like" criticism, but I sincerly think the game stops being fully enjoyable once you find out about all the possible exploits available because this game was clearly rushed out of the production line.It is hard for me to decide if I shall recommend Sorcerer King or not and while writing this review I am still knowing it is going to be a 51/49 close call (since I have to make a choice). So I shall say that I would recommend it on sale, but I will press the "no" button because I think Stardock just lack that finition skills (often because they already moved on the next DLC or next iteration in the franchise) to actually make their games near to flawless, which I am sure they could do if they really wanted to.

Early Access Review
								If you liked Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes, I absolutely recommend Sorcerer King.If you like fantasy 4x games, I absolutely recommend Sorcerer King.If you want to play 4x MPs... then yea, avoid Sorcerer King because it's single player only.The 2 biggest complaints I've been hearing are:1.  You no longer design your own units with equipment the way you did in previous FE games.It is true, you do not.  Instead, you get generic unit types like swordsmen, spearmen, archers, riders, knights, etc.  In addition, you can form alliances with Remnant factions and get unique units that way.However,  a crafting system has been added so you can create armour and such to equip these units!  In addition, equipment can be enhanced!You can't change the weapon the units are equipped with, but you can give them additional armour, and add elmemental damage via rings and such.In addition, designing units was honestly a pain in the butt in the previous games.  When you research new technologies, you got to design the unit with the upgraded equipment.  It felt tedious and time consuming.  Stardock has enhanced and streamlined the unit improvement process in SK compared to FE:LH's static unit designing.2.  It's no longer a true 4X because of asynchronous gameplay (your goal is to kill the sorcerer king, while the SK's goal is to destroy all the shards on the map to become the eternal ruler of the world).Well, AIs tend to be the worst part of 4x games, and generally result in these games offering very little challenge because 4x are generally too complex for an AI to do well (unless they got insane bonuses).  FE:LH suffered from this problem because the AI just wasn't very good at attacking the player or creating deadly armies (e.g. lots of high-initiative ranged attackers).By making the gameplay asynchronous, Stardock made the AI more challenging.  The AI will spawn armies that attack the shards, which you can stop by stationing your armies to fight them off.In other words, both changes actually improved the gameplay compared to FE:LH.Other Improvements:- the graphics are now much more colourful and fantasy-like.- 6 leader types, all of which have their own technology tree and style of play based on their tech tree.- The addition of minor factions that you can sway to your cause, who then assist you with units, technology, and/or resources

												I want to start off by noting that I have not played Fallen Enchantress; but from what I have seen, while Sorcerer King is very similar, it boasts qualities that many might find more appealing.  One such quality is the fact that this game is a casual gaming experience.  (a brief pause for the stereotypical Hardcore players' gasps and shudders)  If you are a veteran 4X player hailing from the lands of Sid Meier's Civilization, Heroes of Might and Magic, or Endless Space, then you might be a little disappointed by the lack of mind bending strategies, depth of min/maxing, or precision fine tuning of global economies.  To be clear, I absolutely <3 all 3 of those games.However, this little gem is great because of it's simplicity.  It taps into the essence of all the things that make the 4X genre great without being overly complicated (or making new users figure out what is going on in the world by using 20 different UI screens filled with charts and graphs).  Each Sovereign has an ability unique to themselves, a Champion (with starting party) that represents how they handle things on the battlefield, and a set of spellbooks.  The spellbooks determine the likelihood that spells of certain categories will appear when you reasearch.The maps are littered with little dungeons, caves, ancient battlefields, etc; each with the purpose of delivering a little comically written quest.  When the quest is done, rewards are given, cake is eaten, and you move on your way to the next quest or enemy army.  Your Champions will level up and gain new abilities as you battle your way to the Sorcerer King's doorstep (he's a total jerk btw).  Battles are fought turn-based on a chess-like grid in a setting that reflects the area you initiated the battle.You will encounter other races that are basically quest givers and potential allies/enemies alike.  The Sorcerer King will be trying to gain their favor as well, and some of them are sworn enemies of each other.  This means that if you ally with one, it might just be impossible for you to become friends with the other.  Having these guys on your side will provide you with periodic trade options, or some other kind of assistance in your efforts against the Sorcerer King.  While they may not provide much direct military support on their own, at least they are with you, rather than against you.If you require your 4X to bombard you with information til your eyes bleed hashtags, then I would move along.  If you're looking for a simple 4X with a casual pace and light hearted spirit, or if you have never played a 4X game in your life and want a good entry to the genre, then look no further than Sorcerer King.

												TL:DR - It’s a good game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys games of this genre.  Read the rest of this review for more detail.I’ll start this review off by saying that I wasn’t a huge fan of Fallen Enchantress or Elemental: War on Magic games.  I found each of them would degenerate into a grind once the initial exploration phase was done with.However Sorcerer King dodges this bullet and maintains it’s pace and interest throughout.  This is basically because it’s not trying to be a fantasy TBS 4X game, it’s more a hybrid between an RPG and a TBS 4X.  I’ll sum my thoughts up with a series of bullet points below:Pros:+  Streamlined 4X elements – fewer cities, more focus on a few groups of units.  Although this will probably deter people who are expecting a pure 4X game.+  RPG/Quests – they’re all basically multi-choice quests that will grant certain rewards based on your decisions.  However they’re well written and grant points associated with your playstyle (for example +1 courage for attacking a group of bandits rather than running from them).  These in turn (as you rack them up) will trigger events as the game progresses.+  Quick, tactical combat – nothing revolutionary but the battles are quick, and straightforward.  The available tactics are limited and generally revolve around clever use of skills and initiative.  They’re much better than in the FE and E:WoM games which had your troops taking 2 or 3 turns running across the battlefield before they’d even be able to enter combat.  +  The doomsday counter and interactions with the Sorcerer King adds flavour and an element of urgency.  It really does feel like you skulking around in the shadows in the first part of the game.Cons-  The AI isn’t fantastic.  I often had enemies run through burning tiles in tactical battles, resulting in them dying when they could have just gone around it.  Also while fighting the ice lieutenant it repeated targeted one of my units that was immune to cold based attacks, leaving my other units to slowly whittle away his health.  Making the combat much, much easier than it should have been.-  As the Sorcerer King raises the threat that he perceives you to be you’ll find that he will send more and more troops against you.  This is fine but they just appear as monster lairs which your borders, which seems a bit of a cheat to me.-  Replayability isn’t fantastic.  I’ve completed the game and all I can do now is more of the same.  The different Sovereigns do make a small amount of difference to how you play but fundamentally the game will largely play out the same regardless.  More winning conditions or different races would make the game much more replayable.Other/General*  Graphics are clean and do the job.  It’s a shame that changing a characters weapons/armour doesn’t show on the unit but it’s not a big deal.*  The music does a good job of reflecting the type of game this is.  Sound is fine.*  I’ve not experienced any bugs while playing*  The crafting mechanic can become a little laborious later on but it’s fun finding and trying out new recipes *  The army design mechanic that was in the previous titles has been removed which may irritate a few people.Anyway this has become a bit of wall of text so I’ll leave it there and add a TL:DR section at the top.

No, the Sorcerer King... who is only referred to as the Sorcerer King an obviously self proclaimed title for a person who's probably named Bob.While it is a very polished in terms of how it runs and what it offers, Sorcerer King isn't for everyone.Let me start this off by stating that this game is very similar to Fallen Enchantress both in its style and aesthetic and that is a game I didn't really enjoy. Not because it was a bad game, but because there are other games that just do things better.Cons: Ranged combat, ranged combat, ranged combat. In battles ranged units can hit anywhere despite line of sight, range or being engaged in combat. (Ah, I'm about to be stabbed by this soldier, let me take a pot shot at that mage across the battlefield.)Aside from ranged combat, the combat in general is probably Sorcerer King's weakest point. The combat feels like a step up from games like Civilization. You move units around on a grid, attack, use special abilities and magic, but the whole experience just feels shallow. I know combat is just one part of the game, but it's something that really needs to be changed if they hope to compete with other offerings in the genre.Pros: The story and world are quite interesting. The premise of trying to unite the lands against a greater evil is pretty unique as well. The game is listed as having A-Symmentrical gameplay and I think it works well. Very few devs try this sort of approach and I must commend them on their efforts. Alone you are weak, but united you just may have a chance against the great evil.Oddities:The humour in this one is all over the place. On a quest to you leap bravely into combat or bravely run away? (Brave Sir Robin ran away, bravely ran away, away!) Some quests are quite humorous while others feel dire. There doesn't seem to be an overall consistency in the tone.Crafting is fun in the early game and every unit can be given items to buff their stats, but it all feels a bit tacked on. 								Will you like Sorcerer King? Probably. You're here, aren't you? That must mean that you have some interest in fantasy 4X or Stardock or the Elemental series. Do you like the idea of a fantasy 4X that borrows ideas from AI War or Star Control 2 and spins it in a unique way?Sorcerer King is an assymetrical 4X game that resembles Arcen Game's AI War and is the product of many lessons learned from the Elemental series. When they say that it's assymetrical, it means that the other 'players' aren't playing by the same set of rules or with the same set of objectives as you are. You're playing a game that imagines that you played the last 4X game and lost. The winner, the Sorcerer King, is now trying to acheive God status and you are only a minor faction among many that attempts to rebuild, and possibly stop him, while negotiating with the countless Sorcerer King armies and deal with the other minors. It introduces a Dungeon Master that will constantly monitor how you play and playstyles that you might be favoring and will adjust the game and the game world accordingly. Using archers too much? The DM might just initiate an event that causes "high winds" and now arrows are extremely unreliable. Using your cavalry units too much? Darn, that horse virus just wiped out half of your horse population. Imagine the possibilities! The crafting system is superb and will only get better. As you travel the world, you'll find different items that will help you craft new armor, new rings, new weapons! You'll also find new crafting recipes, the occasional new item free of the need to craft it, and other awesome stuff. The crafting system is reminiscent of Master of Magic, but now it has a super slick UI and it's been brought to 2014/15. Minor factions are center stage, too. You'll need to woo them and convince them of the strength of your cause. Eventually, we'll be completing multi-stage quests for the minor factions in order to ally with them and gain access to special units, items or other benefits. They speak to you and interact with you in ways very reminiscent of Star Control 2. They aren't  there just yet, but they will be very, very soon.  Also, quests are being written by a Cracked.Com writer and each of them (there will be over 200!) are witty and fun and lead to some really fun choices and exciting outcomes. They're easily the best quest dialogues I've ever seen, including the recent quest-oriented Endless Legend. I've laughed out loud at a few and I'm a hard dog to make laugh. There's more to this game than meets the eye. It's not a re-skin, it's not a reboot. It's an all-new and unique take on the 4X genre that combines the best of the genre with some truly exciting RPG elements. Stardock is a true champion of the genre. With one exclusion, they've made solid 4X games for some time now. Supporting this game and Stardock is supporting the genre and this game is deserving of that pledge of support. Just buy it. The campaign map is big to start with, and I used the zoom frequently ... I learned quickly that the zone of control for cities and outposts is significant, and being able to focus on a tree or a forest (or a continent!) was great. End-of-turn could be a little tricky, but I got the hang of it.Tactical play - given my background (HOMM, etc.), I'm very comfortable with turn-based combat, so this game didn't challenge me too much, as far as mechanics.  The sheer variety of units, along with possible buffs and sovereign spells, kept combat interesting.  I wasn't afraid of using "auto-combat", but would sometimes save the game first, just in case.Bugs - in 40 hours, I had one "no longer responding" crash, which I'm not prepared to fully blame on the game, as I had a number of other things open at that time. So, I sent a couple additional pioneers to the nearby outpost, beefing up its damage, and let it eventually snuff out the little pests. Having played the campaign on "normal" with the Guardian. my plan is to step away and play something else for a while, and then come back and try with a different sovereign; my hope is that the skill differences will be "different enough".  Stay tuned!

												Bottom line, this game is quirky and a lot of fun. It is not as deep as something like Civ, but by shedding that depth it adds a lot of focus. This is not a game where there are infinite possibilities. Every game is pretty much the same, you build a guerilla army until the right moment and then flip the switch to full open rebellion. It is kind of a preset path, but Stardock has made it a really fun and rewarding one. More than any of the other Elemental/Fallen Enchantress games this one really feels like an RPG hybrid. Because the Sorcerer King is always watching you, you have to be careful about where you invest your resources. Build an army that is too large, or settle too many cities and he is going to get upset and crush you. As a result individual champions and settlements become more important. CHAMPIONS: Questing with champions is much more fun in this game than in other fantasy Stardock titles because there are simply so many more quests to go on. The focus on a small guerilla force (at least at the start) makes this questing all the more important. The games crafting system replaces the unit designer of previous games and fits the theme nicely. Rather than pumping out an army of pikemen with flaming pikes, the idea is that you might have a single unit of pikemen but that unit will be kitted out in all manner of cool equipment. If you prefer micro/RPG focussed gameplay as opposed to just spamming huge armies you will appreciate this. SETTLEMENTS: Settlements are a little dumbed down when compared to previous games in the series and very simple compared to the rest of the 4x genre, however, the importance of outposts makes up for this. Because the Sorcerer King will not allow you to possess too many cities outposts become essential to controlling strategic resources and defending your territory for roving enemies. Outposts are upgradable to allow them to better defend themselves and keeping armies nearby to protect them adds an addittional strategic element. MAGIC SHARDS: The magic shards that have always been at the center of the Elemental/Fallen Enchantress/SK series finally live up to their potential here. I remember hearing about these magic nodes in a resource starved world all they way back during the development of the original Elemental and thinking it was a super cool concept. Unfortunately, in execution they were prettty much just like any other resource on the map. In SK the potential is finally realized. Because the SK is actively trying to destroy the shards it creates a real sense of urgency around claiming and protecting them. Every time a shard is destroyed the SK comes that much closer to ending the game. This makes the shards focal points for conflict and expansion, this is finally what I had hoped for all the way back in Elemental.HUMOR: The humor in this game is actually funny. It walks a really fine line between dry and corny, and for me at least, it somehow succeeds. I am typically not a fan of humor in games like this, but somehow the writers carry it off while not undermining the tension of the doomsday scenario theme that forms the core of the game. Sorcerer King is not the new king of 4X. It is not trying to be. It is a niche game in the genre with very focussed gameplay and an emphasis on fun with bright visual and clever writing. If that sounds good to you, I highly recommend it.

At a GlanceI'll start off with a quick summary, for those who don't want to read a long review. Very similar mechanics and play styles as the previous two installments, with a few very different changes and additions. I'll elaborate later on.I DO recommend this game.Overall score: 30/40 = 75%  Category Score   Graphics 7/10   Gameplay 8/10   Sound and Music 6/10   Replayability 9/10 Main ReviewThe main premise of this game takes place after the story line of the previous games in this series, notably Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes. After defeating the Fallen Enchantress, the world is in tatters, all of the Kingdoms and Empires scattered and broken. Your avatar rises to take the lead of your faction, and must rally against the Sorcerer King to prevent the world being destroyed as he attains Godhood.Similar to the previous games, you start with a Hero unit, with some minor units in his/her army. Your hero can found your first city, and then will usually be used to explore the surrounding territory. All over this land there are hostile NPC monsters, bandits, and demons, which you can fight or avoid. These hostile "mobs" typically start off fairly weak, but as time goes on, they do get stronger and more aggressive. There are also treasure chests and quest locations, which will give you items or ingredients, and gain experience for the units that complete those quests.This installment adds some new mechanics, most notably the Doomsday Counter, in order to keep the player progressing. Every so often, the counter will tick up, and if it ever fills up all the way, the Sorcerer King will cast the Spell of Making and destroy the realm, becoming a God in the process.Graphics7/10Same graphics style as the previous games, which isn't photorealistic, but for this type of game, it works really well. I decided to give this one a 7 out of 10, simply based on there being a few odd glitches here and there. One of them being that when you are zoomed out far enough the map changes to a "cloth" style map. This will actually speed up the game as it no longer needs to render so much information. However, when you complete a build order in one of your cities, it will change to the normal style map for a second or two, then switch back to your cloth map. It will usually end up having some tearing and stuttering, with the worst being a CTD (crash to desktop).Gameplay8/10The gameplay runs really similar to the previous games, so if you're a veteran of those you will feel right at home. You are a Sovereign, who guides a fledgling band of ragtag heroes into a mighty Kingdom, able to destoy the Sorcerer King, preventing the destruction of your home. As the Sovereign, you are able to cast a multitude of spells, from different Books. Some spells will affect your cities, adding extra production or food and such. Others are on the "strategic" level, affecting the map as a whole, like raising mountains or making land suitable for settling. There are spells that are used during tactical battles, allowing you to heal your units, speed them up, or directly damage the enemy units, just to name a few. You start with a single "Hero" level unit, along with a couple of minor units in that army. This starting hero can found your first city, with the spawn point usually being the best spot to start off with. A big difference between this game and the previous games, is that instead of paying wages in gold for your armies, you instead generate Logistics which is used at 1 per unit. Various buildings within your cities will improve how much Logistics you make, which in turn pays for larger armies. All of the units, hero and normal, can equip items, like armour and accesories, improving various aspects. One notable thing to remember is that while the hero level units can change their starting weapons, normal level units cannot. All units can gain experience, leading to leveling up, which improves their base stats. You are also able to improve your units by upgrading them once you have researched a higher tier in weapons or armour and so on. This is done simply by selecting the unit you wish to upgrade, and using the "upgrade" order, bringing up a dialog which has your upgrade options.Cities are few and far between in this game, habitable areas being hard to find. While this does make it harder to establish a sprawling Kingdom, it forces you to focus instead on the few cities you do control, and improve them at a steady rate. There are many different buildings to add to your cities, most of them adding basic resources or improving your research rates. Your cities won't add the buildings physically on the map, like the previous games did. There are resources out on the map that your faction can claim, such as metal and crystal. Each node will only add a limited finite amount of resources, instead of generating a set amount per turn, limiting how you use these resources.Finally, instead of having to rely on finding and buying your equipments and items, you can instead craft them. This is new in this game, adding alot more options for customizing your units. Most treasure chests will produce the ingredients used in crafting, with the chests being fairly abundant, the materials are easily obtained. Certain building will also make your resource nodes produce some of these crafting materials regularily, adding a steady income. There is many, many different reciepies for crafting, some added through research, some added through buildings, and some added through quests. There are so many that I havent discovered them all yet, even with the amount of play time I have logged.Sound and Music6/10I found the sound rather lackluster, falling flat at times. This game is an epic 4x strategy, with sweeping stories and fantastic battles, but the music fails to live up to that standard. While it does not inspire greatness, it also isn't annoying and works just fine as background noise.The battle sounds, like sword strikes and spell blasts sound rather canned, like the devs simply didn't decide to put as much effort into that part as they did almost everything else.Replayability9/10While the campaign is a one shot deal, as in it never really changes, the replayability is in the skirmish mode. Random maps, with adjustable difficulties, and many different rival factions, make no two games alike. While you can only play as the Kingdom faction, you can pick one of six leaders, with different perks and powers. Each is tailored to a particular gameplay style, but can be customized to play however you want.SummaryI would highly recommend this game, it is a fun way to while away your time. The strategy is deep, the gameplay is rich, and it keeps the "one more turn" feeling going strong. It has a few issues, but what game doesn't?Excellent game, 30 out of 40! Now get out there and save the world of the Sorcerer King!

Considering it's brand new and not a high price, it's a good one to pick up and sink some hours into. The learning curve is extremely minimal, only taking between 60-90 minutes to grasp the basic mechanics, and then you're quickly onto more advanced strategies and higher levels of aggression. I never found the AI to be devastating however, even on insane difficulties. Sure it would endlessly harass my shards/kingdoms - being a nusance as opposed to a legitimate threat, but it would  never stress me or lure me out.The AI often opts to win by default, by which I mean it throws medium forces at your main force to cause attrition (this doesn't affect the AI because, of course, it has infinite resources and unit production). This also has the effect of causing the 'doom timer' to tick by as you're paralyzed by endless harrying. Sure I guess it's a legitimate battle tactic, but if quickly gets tiresome; it's not intelligence, it's simply an abuse of resource advantage.This is more of a game that attempts to hook you in and then by your own desire you explore the various leader characters and their stats/spells (increasing play time). They do often provide an interesting twist and the skirmish maps were varied enough in scope/scale/challenges/uniqueness that I gave most of them a full playthrough prior to this review. I haven't experiened any significant bugs or crashes aside from one particular frustrating element. When casting hypnosis on specific enemy units (wargs especially) the game would often freeze up on the next manual battle; causing a soft crash. The only cure was to either disband the unit or place them in a keep as stalwart defenders. It's troublesome because hypnosis costs resources and those converted units typically have a good hit point to damage ratio, making them worthwhile units to steal from the enemy. On higher difficulties this ability can really turn the battle and keep things interesting, it's just a shame it causes so much grief (at time of review).That singular issue  aside however, I have had no other crashes or even bugs in the game; it's surprisingly robust. Your experience may vary (the other reviews on here do seem to have had trouble), but frankly I would assume it to be a problem with your system before the game's.It's a good 7.5/10. It's fairly inexpensive, can create some fun adventures (I hypnotised Kevin the Dragon and used his mega Charizard flame burst to literally burn my way to the enemies citadel), and has a good sense of humour in the writing and gameplay. 												An extremely fun turn-based game, with lots of exploration, fighting, and story. 1. One of the great things about the combat is that you can "Auto-Resolve" so that you don't actually have to go into the fight yourself. Personally, I only ever used it when it said "Overwhelming Victory" because I found that sometimes when it just said "Victory" that I might lose a faction, so I participated in those battles just to be safe.2. You have main "Heroes" that you can gather than can lead your armies (yes plural) and you can also make alliances with other kingdoms in order to take down the Sorcerer King. One of the things you have to keep in mind thoughi is that even though you may have gotten an alliance with another kingdom, that ensures that you can't ally with another kingdom because in Dark Ages past, one of them took the other's chewtoy, so Timmy won't be friends with you because your friends with Sasha, who tripped Timmy and embarrassed him in front of the girl he liked. I wished that I could have alligned with everyong, but it simply won't happen in this game.3. At the time of posting this, I have only played 1 game, and that was 17.7 hours long, on Beginner difficulty. Even on beginner, I was faced with many challenges (including learning the game) which definitely kept me on my toes, and still kept the Sorcerer King at the end a challenging battle. (I mean come on, he 1 hit my Heroes, and I only had 1 left at the end of the battle, and I really like my Ranger!) 4. You can equip your Heroes with armor, 6 accessory slots (rings, necklaces, capes, etc.), sword/shield/staff when appropriate, not to mention you can enchant these items. The only annoying thing is that you can't give any weapons to those who aren't your Heroes (even though you can give them accessories and armor...)5. As the role of the Sovereign, you raise your solitary kingdom into a vast empire in order to combat the Sorcerer King, and you yourself have special abilities where you can assist your armies on the battlefield by casting buffs or summoning extra monsters, and you can use various other abilities while in the Tactical Map. 6. It takes Mana and various other things in order to be successful, so when you start out for the first time, I recommend starting on Beginner just so you can learn the basics without having to worry about others aligning with the Sorcerer King too quickly.7. A really neat aspect is that there is technically a time limit on your match. The Sorcerer King is attempting to cast "Doomsday" which will automatically end the game, but you can do many things to prevent it. From the way I played, the highest he ever got was 23/500. By the end of the game, I brought him back to 0. There are many things you can do on the Tactic Map like go to Abandoned Villages, engage in battle, setup Kingdoms and Strongholds, obtain Crystals (Very important!), visit Markets, discuss alliances with others, and more! 8. Wonderful humor! For example: At one time I took my party and we went into a dungeon, and it went something along the lines of this: "Up ahead you see twin ogres sorting supplies for the Sorcerer King's armies. In fact, now that you think about it, all ogres kind of look the same. You racist." On top of that, you can make "Indifferent" choices, "Courageous" choices, "Honorable" choices, "Wise" choices, and more! The most you have of each, the more options you have to use when in a conversation or making choices, like a "Wisdom" choice I made at one point had me talking with a bunch of Wizards studying for their final about the Sorcerer King, and I joined in to talk about my hands-on experiences, or an "Honorable" choice was choosing not to pilfer through graves. It's all good fun, and takes a good amount of time to get stuff done. I found it extremely enjoyable, and definitely recommend it! If you're still unsure, you might want to watch a playthrough and see if it's the thing for you, but I found pretty much everything about this game flawless and a pleasure to play.

When you have a stack of 15 units, all with 12 pieces of equipment...  UI will list all of the items, which make finding things to enchant a pain.  When you enchant an item, it gets moved to the bottom of the list while your cursor stays where it used to be, preventing you from efficiently enchanting an item multiple times (tinkerer can enchant an item 4x).Magic & Spellbook feels really underwhelming in SK.  In one of my game, I selected 8 enchant spell books to try and acquire more unit enchant spells.  I got a total of 4... and been told that I got 8 nice item enchant in the enchantment system instead... (which competes against crafting for mats).  In another game, I picked 4 summons and 4 enchant spell books... I got more unit enchant spells this way... so let's try and figure out how the game works:Wiki/Help - official wiki might as well not be there, because stardocks has made no effort other than setting up a very generic shell.  In game help/spell list is copies over from FE (with some old unused items), and is equally unhelpful in finding/figuring which spell books give what.  Civ has a much better built in help that Stardocks need to start mirroring.Adventure/Quest - while the sorcerer king can temp you with goodies that increase the doomsday counter by 5, the quests from goodie huts can reverse some of that progress.  As the quest locations are fixed, you can plan around it.Bugs - still plenty, such as roads not working in the campaign once your outpost added more roads on top of it.  But it is bearable/Not as bad as WoM.Overall, it is a good first attempt by the team to break out of Stardock's 4X mold and add some freshness in the genre.  But you need to find the courage to think outside the box, and not get tie down by your roots.  More importantly, you need to answer how playing the same thing as diffirent soverign is going to be fun for the gamers?  The game, in its current state, stops being engaging once you figure out how to manage the doomsday counter.TLDR, stick with FE.  You will have fun with it for about 10-15 hours, until you figure out what's buried under the nice looking carpet.  If you need a change, go play AOW or Endless XXX.

												Its a novel take on the strategy genre.  I think it was Rock Paper Shotgun that put it "The game actually starts after you LOST the last one."  The evil dictator won the war and graciously let you live, battered and bloody.  You have to slowly build up a team of fighters while refining your own magic, courting allies, and crafting weapons and armor.  At the same time, the big baddy will court your rivals and try to keep you in check while Doomsday approaches.  The point is a balancing act of expanding but staying under the big bad's notice and ahead of his Doomsday Schedule.Don't be too afraid of that timer, though.  The land is littered in little quest-huts, many of which give you options to slow down the timer.  You can also build (one time) structure in your cities, cast a spell (high cost and cooldown, but repeatable), or beseach a few allies you make to slow down the timer.  I actually beat my first playthrough (on normal) with the counter pushed back down to 0! Think of it less as a timer and more of another resource you need to manage.  Some heroes and abilities even gain power as the timer increases (like production bonus to cities), but if the timer gets too high your population will succumb to despair.  The thralls do nothing but tie up army points of yours... so as I said, its  just something you learn to manage.The main campaign gets pretty stale pretty quickly, though.  The problem is that even the quest huts are static, so you can devise presice strategies to jumpstart your early game like "go south to this inn to recruit this extra unit+quest attribute that lets you bypass the early area and expand quicker so you can then quickly grab this unguarded magic shard...." etc.  There is a random map generator to help alleviate this.  The map size is smaller, but it allows you to play as the other character classes without banging your head into your desk at how stale the campaign can get after a few playthroughs.  The basic core of the game (collect ingredients, train and equip a killer squad, RPG-lite aspect of overthrowing a would-be god) are still solid enough to make the random map scenarious a joy.Overall I whole-heartedly reccomend the game.  The devs should continue making content for the game (they specifically mentioned letting you play as other factions), so there will be more to come!

												I enjoyed Sorcerer King.  Having been a fan of Galactic Civilizations 2, Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes, and to a lesser extent Galactic Civilizations 3, it seemed like a no brainer to try Stardock's latest entry in the Elemental series, especially when Steam had it on sale for less than $12.  I like it and recommend it, with some caveats.  Fans of previous elemental games who are expecting the full 4X experience that Legendary Heroes has will be a bit disappointed.  Sorcerer King feels more like a subgenre spinoff of Legendary Heroes than a true sequel.  While there is exploration, expansion, exploitation of resources, and extermination of foes, all of these things are dialed back in favor of the game's main objective which is to defeat the sorcerer king.  Instead of negotiating trade agreements with other kingdoms, you are now simply attempting to gain their favor so that they will aid you against the Sorcerer King (though the aid really seems to be in name only... I never witnessed any of my allies sending troops to fend off the Sorcerer King's armies).  Alternatively, you can choose to go to war with them and wipe them out, or if they become the Sorcerer King's thralls they will permanently declare war against you.  Also, let's talk about the Doomsday Clock.  It's actually not as bad as it sounds.  Yes, the Sorcerer King does keep building up the timer to doomsday, and when the game first starts and the timer rises it seems pretty hopeless.  Then as you gain power, you find ways to turn back the timer so it's really kind of a non issue.  By the endgame I had completely turned the timer back to zero.  In addition to the trimmed down diplomacy options, the game is also missing one of the best features of previous Elemental games, which is the dragons!  Sure, they were incredibly overpowered, but who didn't love taking over a dragon cave and growing their very own nuclear option that was sure to turn the tide of almost any battle?  Also instead of the many titans that showed up in Legendary Heroes, this game has only two which must be defeated for one of the possible paths to victory.So overall, I enjoyed Sorcerer King though not as much as Legendary Heroes.  For replay value, Legendary Heroes has so much more to do.  However if you enjoy the Elemental series, or Stardock games in general, it's worth picking up and trying, especially if you find it on sale.

												A competant and fun 4X game that doesn't really excel at anything and lacks replayability.  Worth the new low price, especially on sale.The game never quite feels at ease with what it's trying to do; there is a dissonance in almost every aspect.  The serious marketing ("How do you kill a God?") and gloomy premise (bad guy in charge) seems at odds with the almost cartoony visuals and humurous writing.The economic and city-building aspect of the game is so basic and forgettable that you wonder why it's in the game.  It's like Stardock didn't want to fully commit to the nature of the title; building your own stack of doom.  The key of enjoying the game then becomes; how do you build the stack of doom?  Turns out, it's like most other 4X but stripped down.The almost literal handful of units you can train from your cities is adequate at best, and boring at worst.  "Soldier", "Pikeman".  Really?  Even when you pick up a named unit with slightly different stats from one of the (well written) quests, they are usually just slightly different versions of these with the same model and animations. Each Sovereign (your character "class") has access to a unique starting Champion with their retinue, and one or two unique units.  These are the only things that have any character, and unfortunately your first Champion's retinue are not often good enough for end game, so you're left with the champions.  The Champions are cool, there's just nowhere near enough of them.  The ones that are there even share some aspects of their skill trees.  This is because the meat of the game, combat, is quite lacking.You spend a lot of time fighting in Sorcerer King.  The battles are decent scale in terms of amount of units you can control, but they take place in tiny arenas.  There is no room for manoevre or really move at all.  You are right on top of each other.  This was obviously done to speed up the battles, but they went a bit too far.  You know what other 4X has a lot of focus on army building and combat? Age of Wonders 3, which has flanking, area of influence, range, sight blocking along with a massive selection of units.  It does this without the battles feeling any more of a chore than they do in Sorcerer King which lacks most of that nuance.Sorcerer King makes some strange decisions with regards to balance.  Ranged units are able to target enemies wherever they are on the map.  This makes them immediate targets all the time since you can't hide from them, and makes for weird battles where the ranged back lines shoot at each other while the melee units try to reach them.  Another big dropped ball was the way the game handles initiative.  It's turn-based, and turn order is determined by initiative.  Fine.  The game then screws this up by giving you various ways, including a low level spell, to boost initiative.  Which then makes it the go-to thing to boost however you can, since you can often destroy an enemy army without them getting any turns.  This could have been solved by simply having initiative be a strictly inate statistic, or improved only very rarely.  Sorcerer King: The Search for Initiative.The premise is cool, it gives you a singular focus; "I need to make an awesome stack for a boss fight at the end".  Unfortunately any adventure is drained from the experience as it plays out in typically the same way.  There are plenty of quests, but they mostly consist of reading some funny text and then fighting something, typically very easy even if they are labelled as "strong".  It's a fantasy world full of magic where not much interesting stuff happens.  If I'm building a stack, make that stack amazing.  Fill it with characters that you did awesome things with to get there.  But you didn't.  You read some text and fought some wolves, or you clicked a button and trained a cookie-cutter "Sentinel" (not as cool as it sounds)  from your emotionless city.  You can even recruit a Champion by simply selecting a skill on your skill tree.  Narratively justified?  Yes, perhaps, it could be regarded as a reflection of your fame.  But they could have tried to make it narratively interesting.Sorcerer King is a game I wanted to love. A 4X that has me doing something other than running around and destroying enemy cities against poor AI.  They just didn't go all out with it, so you end up doing a lot of the same things anyway.  There is a crafting system, and it starts of cool but descends into tedium as you try to keep your stack not only equipped but those equipped items also enchanted (why can't I do them at the same time??) with an interface that just can't keep up.  Simple things let it down.  When you craft an item, you can have it instantly sent to a unit.  Cool right?  Does it give you a drop-down or grid or list to choose them from?  No, you get a singular field that you must click arrows to cycle through.I am still recommending this game.  It is an overall fun if short experience, with more time in the oven it could have been epic.  I'm not a fan of the visual style myself, but it's clean and there is enjoyment to be had with building your stack of death.  I paid £8-something and got over 15 hours, so that's good value in my book.  Are there better fantasy 4X games out there?  Yes, but this one is worth a play and could get significantly better if supported with DLC.

That was more of a traditional 4X while this launches you into an a-symetric war story.Pros -   1) Good mechanics, deep enough to provide an initial challenge, but not a frustrating learning curve  2) Good lore/story built into play - the player makes choices that matter really frequently  3) Smooth but not awe inspiring graphics (its a 4X game, presumably this is what they're going for)  4) Crafting - has gotten mixed responses with some people saying it's not powerful enough, I find it to be well balanced in terms of time spent crafting to advantage it gives in battleCons -  1) Replayability - On the plus side I played at least a half dozen games on different map sizes and difficulty levels, both of which give a different experience to the game, however:     i) Unfortunately after a couple play throughs you realize that there is an optimal way to build every city and there is no queue, so that means going back to each city every time you build something to figure out where you are in that city's build order (annoying)     ii) Limited number of units and balance between them in the late game makes strategic decisions at the end of the game much easier than at the begining and needs to be developed more, such as balance between mounted units (most powerful) and magical units (severly under powered)  2) Stats and tooltips - Some states just aren't explained anywhere, like Spell Mastery, which seems like it could be important, but I still have no idea after 50 hoursAnyone still reading has seen that despite a couple of issues I have with the game (as of version 1.0), I still reccomended it. 												A game that combines strategy and RPG mechanics all in one package.  Using the same formula as the venerable Lords of Magic and its predecessor Fallen Enchantress, Sorcerer King incrementally improves the formula and manages to build an interesting fantasy setting while it's at it.  With tongue-in-cheek mini-quests that spice up the exploration, as well as a doomsday timer that doesn't let the player simply turtle and assemble an overwhelming army, Sorcerer King manages to maintain a pacing that sometimes eludes long campaign-based strategy games with one big map to explore.  Like the better 4x games, this is a game that grabs you and keeps prodding you to keep going.  I'm 20 hours into the campaign and I've only explored half the map, so we're looking at 40-50 hours for one playthrough.Versus Fallen Enchantress, the campaign feels a little more story-driven than the default map of Fallen Enchantress, but much more open-ended than that game's campaign.  I like the balance they struck with the quest system and dialogue options, giving the world flavor without hemming the player in.  I do kind of miss the linear story, being a fan of RPGs, but this works too.The battle is more refined than Fallen Enchantress.  High-level warriors were essentially invincible in FE and could solo just about anything with life drain equipment (or was it Lords of Magic?).  In Sorcerer King even a high-level warrior with really strong defense can get overwhelmed by crowds of low-level enemies due to stacking flanking bonuses.  This of course works both ways.The scenario encourages rapid exploration to grab crystal fragments, while punishing reckless settlement by drawing increasing attention from your foes, who will send increasingly powerful armies to squish you with each new city.  Building a ton of new settlements all at once early in the game will likely draw swift retaliation and a premature end, forcing the player to strike a balance between beating the doomsday timer and expanding before having the means to deal with the armies of your main foe.In short, if you're a fan of 4X games, especially the fantasy genre, then you should pick this up.

												First off, Sorcerer King is a game I have played extensively as I find it very addictive and enjoyable. It melds together strong aspects of strategy, tactical and RPG games. It also presents a very balanced mix of physical combat and magical combat, conquering the land by clearing it and colonizing it while delaying the advance of the enemy's own conquest, especially the progress of the Doomsday bar, finding and using resources wisely,  researching and making use of spells with temperance. I found that, at its core, it was a game of balance, of equilibrium; you are constantly walking on a suspended rope, and you can only fall once!The graphics are very good, lively and colourful (with a reservation; see observations below). The music is repeatitive, but aptly accompanies the themes of the game, setting a good, heroic playing mood.This being said, a few observations are called for. >The lack of a gamer's manual introduces several problems. It is difficult to understand the meaning of colour codes, for example, without a legend. Game rules have to be discovered as one plays, which presents some interesting late of mid- game... surprises.Let us continue with the User Interface. >When casting the "Heal" spell on an army, why are we shown units in full health? It IS a healing spell. Units in full health hardly require it.>Speaking of that 'healing window', another observation comes to mind. When one selects a unit's icon to become the recipient of the healing effect, it does become very slightly haloed in light blue that hardly stands out against the black background. I supposed I just betrayed my age, but mine poor eyes struggle to verify that the correct unit has been highlighted. Wouldn't it be possible to produce a highlight that stands out much more sharply? I understand that blue is the 'universal' colour for 'good effects' in games nowadays, but how about a more luminescent light blue? Also, do those icons absolutely need to be stacked so closely? If a larger space were managed around each, a halo would be easier to distinguish.>In the city window, over half the space available is taken up by a 'prettily drawn, pretty' picture of an idealized medieval castle. Well done! The actual information windows are very small and, as a result, the useful information is cramped. However, this is not the worst here. The bottom left side panel shows an overview of the city's 5x5 map with very important information regarding the yield of each plot (or tile). This information is not available anywhere else in the game. The icons representing each building your city has produced are lined at the top of this map; once the city has reached maturity, you are unable to see the topmost row of plots, at all. The information you need to decide in which direction you should expand your city's territy, for example, is lost in part, making it difficult to take an informed decision. As far as I'm concerned, this is a design fault. The icons should have been lined down at the right side of the pretty picture, detracting a bit from its amazing awesomeness, no doubt, but allowing us to see what's really important to play intelligently.>Speaking of terrain information, one needs to play extensively to understand that there are really two types of 'pastures' in this game: the rich land that can be settled is dark green (Fertile Land) while the exploitable but 'un-settleble' land is a lime green (Grassland). Yes, one noticed the two colours upon beginning to play, but nothing indicated their meanings, which brings us back to the lack of a gamer's manual. When a settler is selected, the dark green tiles show their yield, which is fine, but other lighter green ones amidst them do not, nor do forests or any other tile. How does one make an informed decision in these circumstances? Select the finest dark green tile, optimally located and hope for the best? That's shoddy strategy. This needs to be addressed. Shadowed yield icons on tiles that cannot be settled, perhaps? > I ought to add that an option should exist, in game, to allow the gamer to see at all times tile yields; I am thinking of a toggle. One may want to see the yields for a while to take decisions, then turn this information off to return to a 'normalized' landscape.>Having to select a spell in three steps each time you need to use it can be annoying and tiresome, especially if you are spamming 'Heal' on an army of 12-15 units, some of which may require several healings. Healing and terraforming spells are frequently used on the strategy map, while combat and summoning spells are used on the tactical map. Why can we not have the use of quick spell bars in each? I'm thinking of the type of bar that permits one to drag and drop spell icons into empty slots, allowing direct access to frequently used spells [Make it a 10-slot bar. Thanks!]. Using the spell book should be reserved for infrequently called upon spells.I am a great fan of building and terraforming. I love to produce maps that are just so. Yes, I am a 'reformed' perfectionist. Forcing myself to apply stamps crookedly on a stack of 100 envelopes taught me a measure of practicality, but once a perfectionist... A couple of things struck me about terraforming.>Although one can research a 'Road' spell at some point, roads are mostly laid out by the program to connect together the various cities and outposts one builds. This is useful and very, very mana economical, but presents one disadvantage; once a road passes through a tile, it is no longer possible to build a village there to exploit its resources or to create a resource using a spell, or to terraform said tile. The problem arises from the gamer's inability to remove a road segment. Once a tile has been amended and built upon, a road can be built or re-built without compromising the changes made. A spell to remove roads is sorely needed!>If I have understood the hierarchy of soils correctly, they are tiered from totally dead (burnt, dead, sand, swampish, etc.), barren, grassland, fertile. The gardener and soil expert in me caught the hiccups upon realizing that sand was classified as dead; desert sand is unproductive because of the absence of water, to wit: oasises. A sandy loam is actually an ideal medium for the production of perfect carrots and potatoes. This being written, I must recognize the creative license of the game's designers. However, when it comes to being unable to change grassland (light green) into fertile land (dark green) while one can change a lower grades of land into fertile land, such as barren land into fertile land or dead land into grassland or even fertile land, I find this quite ridiculous. Such a spell would be mana demanding since it would push a tile all the way up to the very top of the pyramid of fertily, granted, but it should exists in my humble opinion. How many times have I found myself unable to found the city I have been spending hundreds, nay thousands of units of mana to prepare because THE tile that needed to be fertile was merely exploitable? And why are we able to lower entire mountanous areas into grassland this is unusable for purposes of settling? I suppose you intended us to be only able to leverage the one or three mountains in the zone of control of a city, but gamers armed with such a powerful too have other ideas. I'm sorry to say this chaps, but deal with it.In spite of these observations, which address minor aspects of the game, when all is told I warmly recommend this game to lovers of strategy, tactical and RPG gamers.

												I enjoyed this game very much.  Once I got the hang of the mechanics, I found myself playing for hours.  The game shares features from games like Civilization and Heroes of Might & Magic.  It's interesting to start in a game where the evil sorcerer has already won and taken over the land.  At the top of the screen, there's a doomsday meter that fills up every now and then and if you let it fill completely, you lose.  However, in the beginning the Sorcerer King doesn't find you a threat.  Not only does his forces ignore you unless you attack them first (in which case, the game will warn you that you're about to go to war with the Sorcerer King), but you have many opportunities to accept his help.  Sometimes he'll give you supplies, warriors, or magic in return for filling the doomsday bar a bit further.  You can also reduce the meter by completing quests honorably and using an expensive spell that also lowers the doomsday bar.  There's even a hero you can play as who feeds off of the doomsday meter, earning powerful spells and stats the closer to doomsday you are.The dialogue is light hearted and funny.  Even some descriptions of units add a little bit of humor.  The pioneer unit, for example, explains that it is good at creating outposts, good at making settlements, and good at dying if no other units are around to protect it. The mana you gain can be used to cast spells during battle, give buffs to your cities, and even go as far as changing the landscape of the map.  In one such case, I used a spell to destroy a mountain instead of going completely around it.  On top of getting a shortcut to my destination, I also gained some crafting supplies from the rubble. With unique features, such as the doomsday counter, along with  funny dialogue, many spells,  and 9 races/heroes to choose from, Sorcerer King kept me entertained for hours on end.   There wasn't anything with the game that I didn't like.  I just have a few small things I'd like changed/added to the game. I've been playing for 15 hours so far, and haven't come across any glitches.  I recommend this game to anyone who loves fantasy elements with a sense of humor.

Early Access Review
								The TL;DR version of this review is - this is an excellent beta and is shaping up to be an excellent game when released. Anyone who thinks otherwise should go spend some time on the official forums and check out all the features coming to this game in the near future.Here's the long version:Sorcerer King is based on an interesting premise - what if the player and the AI in a 4X game were playing by different sets of rules and had very different goals? And what if those goals put the player and the AI in direct conflict with each other?Sorcerer King takes place in the world of the Elemental series but the general idea is that the traditional 4X game has already happened and the "bad guys" (i.e. - not the player) won the game. The player starts off with a single city and a few units just like in a traditional 4X game. The player will try to expand, recruit units, explore the map, kill things that appear to be dangerous, and do a lot of traditional 4X game stuff.BUT - the main AI in the game, the Sorcerer King is also out there in the world. He already has a pretty big empire. He already "won the game," so to speak. He wants to find and destroy various crystal mana shards that are scattered over the map, release their energy and, in so doing, achieve god-hood and/or immortality. This will also have the unfortunate side effect of destroying the world and killing everything in it. That's where the player comes in - it's your job to stop him by cobbling together the remnants of the other remaining civilizations to form an alliance to defeat the Sorcerer King. It's also your job to protect (and harness the power of) as many shards as you can.Graphics - The graphics are have a nice semi-animated quality that should stand the test of time well. After all, today's "photo realistic" graphics are tomorrow's "Oh God, my retinas are burning!" graphics. The various elements on the strategic map pop and are easy to discern from each other and the background - just what you want from a strategic map in a 4X game. The animations are smooth and consistent.Sound - The sound effects are just fine in that they fit, thematically with the game world and do not break immersion. The music is wonderful, IMHO, and I catch myself humming or whistling it to myself when I am away from the game.Gameplay - This is a beta and not all features are currently implemented. The minor factions, from which the player will carve out a last alliance to save the world, are not yet fully implemented as of the date of this review. However, there is a road map on the official forums that shows the plan for release and they should be fully in game very soon. Even so, the game is still quite playable and enjoyable in it's current state. Tactical combat is fully implemented, the strategic map is fully functional and building and research work as they should. Crafting - I think this aspect of the game deserves it's own section. On the strategic map, players will find chests (AKA - Goodie Huts). But instead of gold or a spell/technology, the player will find crafting materials of various kinds. Crafting materials can also be looted from the corpses of your enemies after a good butt-whipping. An easy-to-use crafting screen shows you what items you can make and the ingredients/materials required to make them. Items range from weapons and armor to scrolls and potions that can be used in combat. There are two very cool things about this - 1) Crafted equipment can be equipped to ANY unit, whether it is a hero unit or just a plain, vanilla red shirted soldier and 2) Non-equippable items (i.e. - potions and scrolls) go into a universal inventory - in other words, you can use a potion or area of effect scroll with ANY unit on the battlefield.Bottom line - Any fantasy 4X fan is only hurting themselves by not buying and playing this game.If you want to see it in action, here's me playing it on Youtube -
