Early Access Review
What is Sorcerer King?A single-player, turn-based, 4X. With tactical combat, a square grid, rpg-mechanics, quests, crafting and magic. Low system requirements (32-bit OS not 64-bit). Clear and attractive art style. Concise and Charismatic Wit Courtesy of Chris Bucholz from Cracked.comEasy to pick up and play. Good for those new to the genre or those looking for shorter, more relaxed games.Not a direct sequal to Elemental:FE/LH, more a spin-off using the same engine. Like DOTA2 isn't a sequel to Warcraft 3. Hey, wasn't this review negative before? What's changed?Mostly it's Bugs squashed! (hundreds dead, or at least licking their wounds)+Quests (hundreds added), a big Balance pass, more content added, Sovereigns got more love... lots of little things from a few extra months of development that all adds up to a generally better, more polished gamePotential negatives that still bother me (even though I understand why):-Simplified/streamlined mechanics, battles, city-building, customisation/design options, no enemy customisation currently BUT Being very streamlined it's so easy to pick up and play, smaller scope helped focus development time and achieve goals-No visual customisation (I hope you like playing as generic humans!) BUT the art is simple, clear, very pretty with high quality animations -If you've played LH you may miss some features (designing race/sovereigns. Wildlands. City specialisations... I have a big list) BUT Doomsday counter and Shard Defence make this game unique.-My interactions with the devs wasn't fun (Epic understatement- banned, old negative review labelled abusive, called arrogant repeatedly etc. so yeah... really not good) and it's soured my enjoyment of the game and watching its development. Unfortunately I feel no joy in seeing that many of my suggestions were implemented/overlapped with the final design direction of the game. (crafting changes, autoresolve changes, first turn introduction changes etc. I posted a lot before being kicked)The key-points:Art-The 3d map (zoomed in) is attractive and very clear. There is no confusion about what a tile contains so you aren't defaulting to the zoomed out view (unlike FE/LH/GalCiv)-Goodie-huts always look like a chest. A grassland tile always looks the same shade of green. A soldier always looks like the same soldier etc.- Each unit and its animations are now hand-crafted. The idle animations are long and interesting.-The sacrifice here is of diversity and customisation. But I think the trade-off to performance and clarity justify the loss. No more headaches like showing a wolf with armour or a human and giant trying to use the same sword 3d model.Single-player-No multiplayer. No co-op. Just you and the SK.-The world feels alive through the writing and linking quest options with intangibles like 'courage' and 'cowardice' that have a host of ramifications-Not being able to change the opponent severely hampers replayability in my opinion. Still Lacking:-Different SK AI-types like you have Sovereigns to choose from-Different Lieutenants much like you have different heroes to recruit each gameTurn-based Strategic map and tactical battles  - Time is a major factor due to the Doomsday mechanic. Waste turns and the Sorcerer King will ally with the minors, destroy the shards and send super-powered armies against you.- You have tools to reduce the doomsday counter and defend shards. But both mechanics are intended to add a little pressure.- Not as easy to play the 'petting zoo' 4x approach of taking your time and ignoring victory conditions to focus on building. The clock is ticking, figuratively.Square-grid, 32-bit and performance- GalCiv3 moved to 64bit and hexes for big epic games with lots of opponents. SK feels bigger by having fewer opponents and player units/cities to manage. If anything the maps can sometimes feel too big, so playing on smaller map sizes is recommended (which helps performance as a side-effect).- Sorcerer King is a smaller, more intimate and familiar game with lower requirements. Cutting certain processor intensive features (unit design, 3d buildings on the map etc.) have, taken together helped to reduce the footprint of the game and improved stability immensely.- Don't expect 10x the map-size and unit-count of LH. It's not that game.RPG-mechanics  -All units can now be equipped with items. After being trained, recruited, summoned or otherwise acquired. But only heroes can change weapons.-Heroes have unique skill-trees. (no changing class, but interesting perks and abilities)-Items no longer change the appearance of units (in general), nor do they have unique 3d models, just icons. - Levels for non-hero units are mostly just HP bonuses.Quests One of the single greatest differences between Sorcerer King and other games is the humour added via Chris Bucholz of Cracked.com. -Light, casual quests and writing should make the game feel less like work. -Lots of quests variety and incentives to play familiar quests differently (to be courageous or cowardly this game) has helped avoid repetition. -Strongly affects the entire tone of the game. For some the humour will hurt immersionCrafting-Items require a recipe, granted by buildings, skills or commonly as quest rewards.-These can then be crafted after you collect enough loot-Later these items can then be upgraded (enchanted) using more loot-Lots of different builds where RNG is a big factor (what can I craft/enchant this game?)Magic - In complex design terms:  the gloves are off! - Familiar spells from previous games reappear with new artwork, but there are more spells like volcanoes/terraforming that wouldn't fit in a standard 4x except as end-game super-weapons (overpowered, abusable in MP). Here some are starting spells and it works... mostly.- Sovereigns have a selection of magic books which unlock spells for research from Wrath/Enchantment/Summoning etc. The magic you use really changes from game-to-game and sovereign-to-sovereign. Tactical Battles - Small. Fast. Simple (but... Boring.)- Armies now have a combat rating. (autoresolve strength) - Safely autoresolve 'overwhelming victory' predicted results with no losses. Leaving you to focus your time on just the important battles. - Limited tactics during battle. No terrain effects, height, weather, cover, flanking*, range penalties etc. (*there is a swarm bonus for surrounding enemies) -Poor boss-battles. 3 Big units with lots of HP that die in rather anticlimactic and repetitive ways. Simplified 4X -Generally one of the most streamlined and straightforward 4x games around. The core elements are simple to understand nothing too confusing or deep. -No influence/economic/alliance/quest victory types (unless you count killing the SK as completing your quest).-Some additional options (e.g. spell of making as the Tyrant).-No open borders, treaties, trade routes, production chains, civic research etc. very simple to play  In summary. If you are: New to the genre and haven't played 4x/RPG games before or perhaps you are looking for something different then this does scratch a very different itch to Elemental:FE/LHBUT If you wanted more complexity, deeper mechanics, longer battles, lots of customisation or to play with friends you may be disappointed.

								This game has come a long way and is now more or less release-ready (and it will be out of early access next week, I believe).If you loved prior games from the Fallen Enchantress series, then you'll love this game. It's a really good fanasy 4x game with RPG elements for your heroes and armies. Nonetheless, the game engine continues to stutter and pause unexpectedly on larger maps, even with a 64 bit operating system, 16 gigs of RAM, a GTX 970, and the fastest i5 processor currently on the market. But, the stutters and pauses aren't as bad as in previous games. Graphics are passable but not great. It's like a civilization game: you don't play it for the graphics. You play it for the gameplay.And the gameplay has a lot of interesting features, a few of which I've never seen in a 4x game before. The most notable feature is the doomsday counter. You see, the bad guy (the Sorceror King) has already won. You were one of his generals who is now in charge of a city. You learn he is planning a doomsday spell to end the world, so you decide to revolt. But, he doesn't know you're revolting yet. This makes things VERY interesting because:1) If you reveal that you're revolting from him before you're strong enough (by your diplomatic interactions with him, by attacking his forces, or by other interactions) then he'll send his forces against you and wipe you out, and 2) If you don't defeat him by the time the Doomsday counter is full, then the world is destroyed and you lose. So #1 forces you to be stealthy, in a way, and #2 forces you to be aggressive. But being too aggressive too early means you'll fail at #1 and he'll wipe you out. In other words, you have to walk a fine line and use REAL STRATEGIC THINKING when planning things out. Also, you can accept help from the Sorceror King to bolster your forces (he believes you're still on his side after all, at least initially), but doing so advances the doomsday counter.Guys, I can't tell you how absolutely GENIUS and BRILLIANT this gameplay mechanic is! You have to walk a fine line or all is lost. This is the BEST innovation in 4x gaming since the original Civilization game came out, in my humble but expert opinion!You can find great gear by completing quests or defeating powerful enemies, but often the best gear is made by crafting - after you get the blueprint and crafting components by, you guessed it: completing quests, defeating powerful enemies, and opening chests spread randomly over the map (which usually only contain crafting components, not actual treasure.) There's also a ton of spells to research, that your sovereign casts, and combat is turn-based. So you get a fantasy Civ game with RPG elements, with a combat system a bit like the Heroes of Might & Magic or games of that ilk. So, all in all it's a great game with a few new and interesting ideas that make gameplay interesting and unique enough to make this game stand out from the crowd. It's easily Stardock's best 4x fantasy strategy game yet.

Early Access Review
								As of writing, the game just got a balance pass, and everything is kicking into high gear!Sorcerer King is an asymmetric 4X, which basically means the enemy (the Sorcerer King) has already won, and you play a minor faction secretly (or openly) building up your forces and biding your time to one day stop the Sorcerer King from casting the Spell of Making and becoming a god and ending the game for you. Along the way, there are other minor factions who may choose to ally with you, or (the rogues!) with the Sorcerer King.Where the game shines is in the many interlinking systems that make up the customization and gameplay. There's the crafting system, which allows you to create armor, weapons, scrolls, potions etc. from found loot, and equip them to your units, giving a really good way to 'build up' your forces, and in a really organic way. There's the Shards system, which calls for strategic planning of where to place your cities and outposts in order to harvest all-important Shards which generate Magic, which is split into your Skill, Lore, or Mana (basically ruler abilities, research points, and currency.)Skill allows you to choose abilities in your Sovereign skill tree (ruler abilities), which vary according to your choice of Sovereign, and which grow alongside individual Champion trees for each of your Champions (hero units.) Lore (research points) can be used to choose one spell out of a randomized short list of available spells, which keeps each choice fresh and makes every choice important. Mana is your currency for casting these spells, and for other things like unit abilities and fast-buying city improvements.Cities grow organically, according to their Food production, and as they level, you choose the next tile to expand into, depending on the Labor, Food, or Essence of that tile. Labor determines how fast your improvements and units build, while Essence determines how many City Enchantments you can cast on it.All in all, the game is, even in this beta stage, a wonderful amalgamation and interlinking of all these systems. Every choice you make feels important, because it is important, because it affects some other thing that will affect some other thing in the game. At the end of the day, you're not simply making optimizations or doing management, but making some small degree of impact upon your final victory or defeat through each individual choice in all the different systems and mechanisms that come together to form the game.Tactical combat (yes! tactical combat!) is square-grid based, and is snappy and to the point. Here too, choices matter, in tactical decisions such as movement, placement, ability usage, Sovereign spell casts, etc. Death for each unit feels final, as there aren't many ways to bring them back, and somehow you end up caring for each unit. Whether this be through their accumulated XP and levels, the equipment you put on them, or just because each unit plays an important part in every battle, or because a lot of them come with a cool backstory (like horse thieves that you forcefully reform into solders) or because you can name them silly names like Ben or Bill, it all really feels great, and you start to care for your men (though they're not always 'men.')Exploration on the beautifully-drawn map is a joy. The landscape is lush and filled with treasure chests of resources for crafting, lairs of monsters for you to do heroic (or unheroic things) and gain XP and sweet loot, terrain of differing kinds, and outposts and cities of the other factions and the Sorcerer King. As you explore, you are faced with choices at each lair that gains you points in Compassion, Cowardice, Fame, Intimidation, and other personal qualities, that go on to have game effects according to each quality that you become strong in. The stories are entertaining, and multitudinous enough to not feel too repetitive, and each choice results in differing results with both combat and non-combat consequences.The only thing the game is missing IMHO right now is more playable races, but this can be fixed in future expansions or DLCs if the developers will it. The devs are friendly too and responsive to forum posts, and run a weekly (or thereabout) dev stream on Twitch where you can chat to them directly.I'm not new to Stardock's style, and have played plenty of other 4X's in different genres (both sci-fi and fantasy), but Sorcerer King is a definite gem with lots and lots of potential. Support this awesome product to see it grow with more expansions!Definite thumbs up, YES, YES, YES I recommend this game.Edit: Forum peoples are concerned about the Sorcerer King countdown, which is the countdown to the god-becoming spell that the Sorcerer King will cast. But there are actions and events in the game that slow the countdown or even set it back, so the countdown has elements of a push-and-pull between you and the Sorcerer King, and is not entirely an unstoppable timer. The countdown can also be set in the options to be slow.You may or may not have a preference for the countdown, but it's not as bad as it sounds (this coming from someone who also had the same understandable knee-jerk reaction against a 'time limit'). But it adds a good amount of urgency to your actions without becoming unbearable, and is a great push towards achieving your goal in the game.

								What is Sorcerer King?An expansion of the Elemental games?  No.  And this seems to be a lot of the problem that people posting negative reviews have.   SK is a different game set in the same universe.   If you play the game from that mindset, you will find a lot in SK to like.There are enough similarities to the other Elemental games that you will get a nice, warm, notalgic glow from playing, but not so much that it feels like the same old game.The game, while still strategic, moves at a much faster pace.  The Doomsday Counter is the bane of those who prefer to sit back and methodically build an empire.   The graphics style has changed.  Some will see this as an improvement, some won't.  Personally, I like the new style much better than the old.  Although you can rename any unit in your army, designing your own units is gone.  Basically, you unlock unit types which you can then build if you have the necessary resources. Apart from hero units ( of which there are much fewer ) , Individual units do level up and can be customized to certain extent, but not to the extent of the other Elemental games.The best way to describe Sorcerer King is that it is a much more focused game than its Elemental brethren.  The point of the game is to stop the Sorcerer King - not to build a huge sprawling empire.  If you spread your empire too far and too fast, the Sorcerer King's minions show up on your doorstep to crush you.   Of course, if you spread too slow, they eventually show up and crush you anyway too.So, should you buy Sorcerer King?If you are looking for an expansion of the previous Elemental games, I would say no.  But if you are looking for a fun game in the Elemental universe, I would say, definitely.As game balancing improves, the game can only get better and better.I say to you, "Go forth and stop the apocalypse ! Atm will list as pro.* Sovereigns: I like the overlooking ruler with a skill tree of their own to aid the minor faction as it grows to a kingdom able stand agaist the SK..* Magic: Having limited spells in combat is a nice touch. Pick what you need to win or aid you vs unlimited access in FE* Champions: Again less is better. One or two to make it count is better. Take your champion were its needed instead of one for every army. Only grip is how quickly the skill tree maxes out. Some skills seem kind of lame, some  are supper cool really only giving me the desire to use on or two since the others are clearly less effective.* Logistics: Great concept. Army count based off support of city and buildings built. Just takes the burden out of the players hands to micro manage finances. Now just field your armies and enjoy the game with the logistical count available.Whatevers:* Single city tiles (SK) vs build on towns (FE). Personally I liked the build on town in (FE). This was a very unique design that mad it feel as if my towns were growing in size and scope. I also like the simple version of the single tile system. It is very clean and still changes as it grows taking much less space so max level cities are not hording the map realestate, limiting room to march armies or having the AI go for one more town that won't grow right next to you.* Army size: (FE) had what I thought to be pretty cool units size. Individual, squad, company, etc. Ths idea was completly thtown out in (SK). I personally like the growing army size in (FE) but seeing as units start with 1x3 size its sort of a wash aside from the odd 1x1 units you start with or aquire through the course of gameplay.Resources: Logistical build vs stockpiling resource. Both seem to have useable functions to the game and add their own flair. Set amount to use (SK) vs limited to abundance through gameplay (FE) Cons:* Although the overall look and feel has been enhanced, the overall game just seems to be lacking some functional depth. The concept of the game is epic. An all powerful sorcerer king has begun his actions to end the world as we know it and yet it just doesn't feel translated into the game as it progresses. * Battles: For me they lasted roughly half a turn, maybe one with me. I usually never feared the death to my mundane groupe of soldiers. There is never a real sense of a armies clashing taking place. Since battle is fairly weak there is no real need for strategy in the much more defined battlemap and its choke points, no need for diverse units and no need for the plethera of now worthless spells to cast or special moves. Why cant some depth be given to city/ castel fights. Walls, ramparts, towers? Something to make it feel more grand. No this is not Total War but, it is still a castle.* Magic: Lots of spells, most seem useless or a repeat in a different form. Without a variety of foes, weaknesses and strengths, there is not much need for a variety of spells. Tactical: Since battles end so quickly why the need for lots of options? You wont get to use any. Though (FE) battles lasted a little longer the same problem persists. There isn't much stategic value using them when other skills can be employeed over and over at the same result or faster. Casting the spell just takes a move away from my unit to give a crap bonus for or against when I can just walk up and hack it. Strategic: Lots of them that just seem unbalanced, wasted time, or a rarely seen or valued opportunity to cast aside from city enchantments. Limited terraforming spells in this rendition seem pretty usless or bugged at the moment.* Crafted Items: Great idea, aweful excection. I can make cool items to give my hard working soldiers and champs!? Here guys try this piece of crap I made for you that really doesn't change a thing! Who cares about a ring that give a mighty +1 hp. Are you kidding me? Outside the armors, most craftable items are a waste of time and resources that wont effect much unless enchanted which really only has about 7 options at this time. The rest of your options come from loot infused as enchantment which takes up far too much space instead of being stacked for a quick easy look at what you have relative to what it does. We dont need 4 items scattered across 3 pages to know we have a lot of clouded rubies. Important resources for the nice gear are just too infrequent to make me care about the process. Waapons should progress allowing a nice order and time frame from low to high instead of being able to make two (worst and best) skipping all in between by the time I get said resources. * Cities: Appear to have been turned into very basic linear choice without much variety. Since your choices of where to build have relatively taken away there aren't bonus structuers, such as being next to a river like a dock (FE). Could we also try the previously mention here too? Units should stack as army inside the city for one option, not each. Not a nig deal but its just the missed attention to detail that nags at me and being tired of looking at my army of administrators..*Outposts seem more for decoration and tower defense than an integral part of the game outside of grabing a resource. I loved them in (FE) for atk/def/ move bonuses and population boosting. Felt more like expanding my kingdom instead of putting up a sign.* Though AI turns move faster the overall game seems to as well, as if some of the meat has been taken out to give you a very fast unengagging flat experiance. The graphics and art may have improved along with a few new or improved concepts but sadly thats about where it ends.In closing I will say I just expected and hoped for more. At this time if it stays as it is and at the current cost, so should you. Wait for a special. If you want something quick and easy with little fulfilment or attachment, this is for you.

												This game is amazing. _Elemental: War of Magic_ was a great idea, implemented poorly; this is a brilliant idea, implemented very nicely indeed (although it does make my computer, which can run _Skyrim_ all day without trouble, run surprisingly hot). This isn't quite the world's first successful strategy-RPG -- the first game which is both uncompromisingly a strategy game and uncompromisingly a Japanese-style RPG -- but it shows what that game would look like; among the secrets are sharply circumscribing the range of available possibilities, and creating a scenario which can play out in broad strokes that the game can recognize, even when the details are wildly different from game to game._Sorceror King_ is also a worthy successor to _Master of Magic_, probably the first game that can really call itself _Master of Magic 2_. It even includes the part where High Men Paladins are a strategy in themselves :) -- and more seriously, it has the exact same feel, but more modern, more fully implemented and fleshed-out. Your character is more sympathetic, too, unless you go out of your way to choose the evil vassal.As a game itself, it's superb -- although also horribly addictive in the classic just-one-more-turn manner of spacefaring 4Xes. I can recommend this too strongly, if there's anything else you want to do with your life; but still, it's really, really good.Atmospherically, the game is odd. The Sorceror King is plotting to destroy all life and absorb the whole world into himself; he's a savage brute, a torturer and slave-driver; but he's just so _gullible_. And _helpful_. If he went to Atlantic City he'd get scammed in shell games. Even though he's an absolute moral monster, I almost feel _guilty_ about stabbing him in the back.(By the way, there's a spell which the Sorceror-King is unimaginably weak against. Make modest use of it, and you can cheese the game; you can win well before what was supposed to be the halfway point. The miracle spell in question? Raise Terrain.(Create Road is pretty game-busting, too.)

								I cannot begin to tell you just how much you should avoid this game. I generally only bother to write a review when I have major problems with the purchase. In short the main reason not to buy this game is the Doom counter, or meter which when fills results in an automatic loss. I just had my game end just like this on turn 74. It is a poor idea for any 4H game, however in its current iteration in this game, you are not just rushed, you are basically going to lose regardless.Playing it on normal, in some scnarios you can go on for quite a while. However if the enemy decides to start destroying shards, which are all over the map. You have no way of stopping it. Especially when they start early on. You simply cannot get there, the maps are pretty big. Even the medium sized ones. There seems to be something in the order of 50 shards on the map with the FEW shards option checked in map creation. The enemy "Sorcerer King" starts with units in virtually every inch of the map. And these are the guys who kill off the shards.It boggles my mind how something like this even made it past the planning phase, much less got in the game. The community (forums) for Stardock are exclusively fan boy driven. I think this game is a case where it was developed in a vacume and the devs and the fanbois colluded together and simply drank their own coolaid. The end result is a very poor game with a broken mechanic (timer) that should never be in a game like this. If you like to take your time, develop your lands, characters, and armies....this game is not for you. In many cases  even at break neck speed the timer will finish with you losing no matter what.Other comments: This is an in house game engine that they have been using for  a few years. It still has a decent sized memory leak that has never been fixed to date. However you can play for about a few hours before it starts act up and crash. The graphics have not been updated and it seems like they made the detailed play map dissappear at any distance away to try and improve performance. The result is in order to see anything other than a cloth map you have to be zoomed in till it feels like your face is next to the ground. I did not like this, and I do not remember any of the previous games doing this.The game balance is still wonky, It's in beta (but nearly complete) but that is to expected when the last touches are going into the game. They have made the unit creation pretty boring, you can create a basic soldier, pikeman, archer, armor warrior,  rider, paladin. And that's it. You customize them with gear, but then....who has time for that thanks to the timer? There are less heroes, you might be lucky to get 3 maybe 4. Lack of AI: this series continues to have bad AI. This game in particlar is the worst I have seen in awhile. Civilization 1 has better AI than this game. The factions...if you can call them that, do nothing. They don't attack you, they don't build armies and fight each other or the Sorcerer King. They sit there, they don't found towns. And this is just the strategic AI. The tactical combat is no better really. The AI does seem to pick your weakest members, but almost any mechanic that might have made combat interesting has been removed, ostensbily because the poor AI can't handle it.That means ranged characters have no range....that is they can hit you anywhere on the map, through trees, over walls. It doesn't matter. God forbid the AI have to position themselves for a shot. The fact is the AI is basic so mechanics like these are not possible. (See Jagged Alliance, now 10+ years old for a game that was able to do this.). The castle sieges are the same old tripe as in previous games in the series. With some basic obstacles being put in place (barricades) which can be used as cholepoints, which does at times make it feel like there is some stragey.

												Sorcerer King is a great mash-up between the rpg style of Heroes of Might and Magic (HoMM) and the 4X city-building of Civilization/Fallen Enchantress/etc.Game Characteristics:- Easily my favorite feature so far is the humor with which the game is written. The quest text is actually worth reading as it is a) brief and b) usually interesting/humorous. I've had a couple laugh-out-loud moments, and that doesn't happen often in a game that isn't Portal. Some people have called the writing style "snarky", but I hate that word and those people. Pick a better word. I'd suggest "funny" or "sarcastic".- The devs have REALLY reduced the amount of micro-management, at every level, that you have to engage in over the course of a campaign. There is city building, but it is not as involved as a game like Civilization. I actually find this to be a pro because of the focus on running my hero around as opposed to checking 5 cities every turn. It is, however, more robust than I remember the old HoMM's being. Expect to have your cities queue up a new project every 2-20 turns, and take care of themselves largely in between.- Much like the limited city-building, there is very little management at the empire level. You have a shared pool of resources that you split between your tech tree research, spell research, and mana pool. The tech and spell trees are small compared to a game like Civilization. However, each choice has a pretty big impact and all the spells I've come across are regularly useful instead of being filler or only applicable in rare situations. Mana powers your spells on the map and in combat, and also serves as currency to rush build things a la money in most other games. - So if you aren't managing 50 different details of your city and empire, what do you spend your time doing? The majority of your time in Sorcerer King is spent running your army or armies around the map and getting involved in HoMM/King's Bounty-style turn-based tactical combat.- I'll start with the overworld map play. You run around a vividly-colored world that is surprisingly charming for a realm that has been devestated by the eponymous wicked Sorcerer King. The landscape is brightly colored and has a fair bit of cartoonish detail. Think more World of Warcraft than Gears of War. There are a ton of treasure and quest sites scattered around, which, when coupled with some fast-travel spells, really reduce the number of "dead turns" in which nothing happens.- I play on Hard difficulty, and I've found the tactical combat to be varied and satisfying. I'm a veteran player of these sorts of games (HoMM, King's Bounty, XCOM, etc) and I find in most fights I can micro-manage my way to a victory without losses. It takes some brain power though, and in some fights I've had to either accept losses or reload and change tactics. This game is usually fair but is also unafraid to hand you a challenge that makes you pay attention. There is a good amount of variety in skill types between the hero and non-hero units, which helps keeps the fights interesting. You won't spend much time just auto-attacking your way through a fight as quickly as possible, at least not if you want to come out of it unscathed. You can auto-resolve combat if you wish, although I'd only recommend it against opponents much weaker than yourself.- As with the tech and spell trees, the hero ability trees have been pruned down so that most if not all choices are a big step up in power.- The last thing I'll mention is that there is not much depth in kingdom vs. kingdom play, and that has discouraged some customers. Your grand opponent every time is the Sorcerer King, and his doom-timer sets a turn limit every game, although some spells, techs and quest resolutions will let you gain more time. There are other factions, but they function more like minor cities/factions in other 4X games as opposed to fully-featured opponents. You will engage in diplomacy/name calling with the other factions, and the Sorcerer King checks in on you frequently and will even give you support (at a price) at the start of the game until you ♥♥♥♥ him off. Expect a few chuckles and some quests/heroes/artifacts from the other factions. Do not expect epic, drawn out, multi-front battles across lots of territory.- I have not checked to see how others are doing, but I personally have not run into any bugs at all while playing this game.Conclusion:I have enjoyed my time with Sorcerer King so far, and I look forward to continuing play and trying out new sovereigns and heroes. On the surface the game may seem surprisingly casual for a Stardock title, but there is a lot of depth and fun to be had in this title. Frequent small rewards, interesting combat, great writing, colorful art, and a reduction in tedium all make this game worth checking out for fans of the genre. I give it a solid 8/10 and will recommend it to my friends.

												A solid strategy game. I like the way the game unravels the more you play, discovering more features as you progress as you try to build a large army without arousing suspicion from the Sorcerer King. It's a pretty great concept and it allows you to use him to your advantage but usually at a cost, the Sorcerer King needs you so he can kill everything and claim the world for his own, but he is ever watchful of your actions. The many missions you find are enjoyable and are also rewarding, depending on the outcome you can get different buffs, items to craft and special equipment to strengthen your armies and it could speed up or slow down the Sorcerer King's world domination. You too are a demigod like the Sorcerer King, but weaker than him at the start, so you too can learn spells to influence and alter the gameworld and battles, which I like alot. Love the graphics and art style. Ranged combat is rubbish though as they can shoot through and over everything, there should always be a line of sight mechanic for ranged combat or it just becomes a broken game mechanic.By the end of the game, you'll have seen alot, explored alot, got lots of rare treasure, done lots of quests with boss battles, allied with many factions to help you stop the Sorcerer King, crafting many great items as you improve and strengthen your army units and eventually stop an evil presence. A very enjoyable and wholesome strategy experience which cannot be missed.

												Sorcerer King is a turn-based strategy game that has some similarities with my two other favorite games; Civilization III and Heroes of Might and Magic III.   The game is filled with skill choices for your champions and soverigns, and the world is steeped in magic.  One of my favorite features of the game is the ability for the game to create a random world.  This feature will give the game an extremely long life in my "favorites" library.It is taking me a while to figure out good strategies towards winning even one game, but I think I am getting close.   I have a tendency to want to skim the rule book and play any new game as soon as possible, so I can learn by doing, then refer to the manual as a reference book.  Admittedly, once I finally found a downloadable PDF rule book on the web, I had to lean on the book more than usual.  (Note to developers: Include a rule book with the game.  Do not make us search Google.)If you jump right in, you might become frustrated with a very basic problem: How do you end your first turn so you can begin your second turn?  I tried viewing videos, reading blogs, and I even tried punching random keyboard keys but could not figure this out for quite a while.  I was not happy.Here is that very basic answer.  Take a look at the lower right corner of your screen.  There will be a red rectangular button that explains what you need to do before the game will proceed.  Click this.  It may ask you to choose a new spell to research, or that your champion or soverign has completed a task and you need to choose what he should study next.  To the left of this rectangular button you may see a red round with an exclamation mark.  Click this to resolve other options.Another feature that was not fully explained, is the Enchantments options.   So far, I have always chosen the blacksmith guy as my beginning soverign dude, therefore he has access to creating and enchanting items at the very start of the game.  In the Enchantments screen, you will see that some enchantments may require you to destroy a blue gem to gain a +3 to Speed, but there are other icons that look like a scroll with a Roman numeral on it, such as Summon IV.  If I am guessing correctly, you can always reproduce the "crush a blue gem to add a +3 Speed" to a new item, but the Summon IV can only be used once per game.If you like Heroes of Might and Magic III, I think you will love this game.  But you might want to make sure you can find and download the manual before you commit to the purchase of the game.
